messageBody:
On Friday 05 November 2004 05:51, timotius_pamungkas wrote:
> Hi all,
>
> I'm new in JUnit and want to ask a question. Suppose I have a
> MyRectangle class with this method :
>
> public void setWidth(int w) throws IllegalArgumentException {
> if (w < 1) {
> throw new IllegalArgumentException();
> }
> width = w;
> }
>
> and this junit method :
>
> public void testSetWidth() {
> MyRectangle rect = new MyRectangle();
>
> Assert.assertNotNull(rect);
> rect.setWidth(-5);
> Assert.assertEquals(-5, rect.getWidth());
> rect.setWidth(4);
> Assert.assertEquals(4, rect.getWidth());
> }
>
> When I call rect.setWidth(-5), it should be throw an exception, and
> it really throw an exception. The problem is, my test stop at that
> point, so rect.setWidtt(4) never executed. But all I need is it
> really throw an exception or not. If it's throws an exception, that
> means the method is correct, and the JUnit should continue with next
> test. But if it didn't throw any exception, that means the code is
> wrong (maybe I forget to check the parapmeter), so if this happen, my
> Junit will stop. How can i create this kind of test?

Don't try. Write two tests.

Write a test to ensure that correct width-setting works:

public void testValidWidthSetting()
{
MyRectangle rect = new MyRectangle();
rect.setWidth( 17 );
assertEquals( 17, rect.getWidth() );
}

[You *don't* need to check `rect` is non-null; if it is, the
JVM is broken; all bets are off, anyway.]

And another to check that the exception gets thrown:

public void testInvalidWidthException()
{
MyRectangle rect = new MyRectangle();
try { rect.setWidth( -42 ); fail( "illegal width should be detected" ); }
catch (IllegalArgumentException e) { /* yes, nothing */ }
}

And if a lot of your tests start with

MyRectangle rect = new MyRectangle();

make it a fixture of your TestCase.

--
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
